key_points: The Ever Given, impounded after blocking the Suez Canal, holds goods worth millions for companies like IKEA and Lenovo.
Companies face a protracted legal battle to recover goods stuck on the Japanese-owned vessel since March.
An Egyptian court impounded the Ever Given due to a $916 million compensation claim by the Suez Canal Authority against the ship's owner.
Goods worth between $600 million to $700 million are stuck on the ship, affecting both large corporations and small businesses.
Affected companies, excluded from negotiations, may have to pay a portion of the settlement under the "general average" maritime law principle.
Shoei Kisen Kaisha (ship owner) and the Suez Canal Authority have not commented on the situation.
Several companies, including a UK bicycle maker and a commercial refrigerator supplier, fear significant financial impact.
IKEA and Lenovo confirmed they have products on the impounded ship but offered no specifics.
Businesses complain about being left in the dark regarding the status of their goods and legal negotiations.
The situation causes major cash flow issues for businesses, especially smaller ones without marine insurance.
spokespersons: Jai Sharma (Head of Cargo Casualty, Clyde & Co.)
